title: Caenorhabditis elegans as a Model System for Discovering Bioactive Compounds Against Polyglutamine-Mediated Neurotoxicity
procedures:
NOTE: See Table 1 for the recipes of solutions used in this protocol.
1. Preparation of materials for the Caenorhabditis elegans assay
Maintenance of C. elegans strains
	
Obtain C. elegans (AM141 and HA759) and Escherichia coli (OP50 and NA22) strains (see the Table of Materials).
Maintain the nematodes on the nematode growth media (NGM) plate seeded with E. coli OP50 at 20 °C for AM14121 or 15 °C for HA75923.
Preparation of E. coli OP50 bacterial culture
	
Pick a single colony of E. coli OP50 from a Luria-Bertani (LB) streak plate and inoculate it into 50 mL of liquid LB culture.
Incubate the OP50 bacteria in a shaker at 37 °C and 200 rpm until an optical density of ~0.5 at 570 nm (OD570).
Store the OP50 bacterial culture at 4 °C and use it within two weeks.
Preparation of NGM plates with OP50 bacteria
	
Add 20 g of agar, 2.5 g of peptone, 3.0 g of NaCl, and 975 mL of deionized water to a 1 L autoclavable bottle. Autoclave at 121 °C for 30 min.
Place the liquid NGM agar bottle on the bench to cool to ~60 °C, and then add the following sterile stock solutions: 1 mL of 1 M CaCl2, 1 mL of 1 M MgSO4, 1 mL of 5 mg/mL cholesterol, and 25 mL of 1 M potassium phosphate (pH 6.0).
Pour 20 mL of NGM into a sterile 90 mm Petri dish, and leave the plates on the bench to cool and solidify. Keep the plates upside down and allow them to dry on the bench at room temperature for 2 days.

Dispense 200 µL of the OP50 bacterial culture onto each NGM plate and spread evenly with a sterile glass coating rod. Close the lids and incubate the plates overnight at 37 °C.
Store the NGM plates seeded with OP50 in a plastic box with a cover at room temperature and use within two weeks.
Preparation of age-synchronized C. elegans population
	
Collect gravid adult nematodes into a sterile 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube and centrifuge at 1000 × g for 1 min. Wash three times and resuspend the nematodes in M9 buffer.
Add an equal volume of bleach solution and agitate gently for 3-5 min. Monitor the bleaching every 15 s under a dissecting microscope.
		NOTE: The bleach solution must be prepared freshly before use by mixing equal volumes of 10% NaOCl and 1 M NaOH (Table 1)20.
Once most of the nematodes are broken, stop the digestion by diluting with M9 buffer. Quickly centrifuge to remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in M9 buffer to repeat the washing three times.
Resuspend the pellet in S medium. Let the nematode residues settle down by gravity for 2-3 min while the eggs remain in the supernatant.
Aspirate the supernatant into a new sterile microcentrifuge tube. Collect the eggs by centrifugation at 1000 × g for 1 min.
Discard ~80% of the supernatant and transfer the eggs into a sterile flask containing 20 mL of S medium. Place the flask in a shaker and incubate the eggs overnight without food at 120 rpm to obtain synchronized L1 nematodes.
2. PolyQ aggregation assay
Preparation of nematodes for the polyQ aggregation assay

Transfer 300-500 synchronized L1 larvae of AM141 to each well of a 48-well plate with 500 µL of S medium containing OP50 (OD570 of 0.7-0.8) and 5 mg/mL of astragalan, typically one well per treatment for one time point.
Seal the plate with parafilm and incubate at 20 °C and 120 rpm for 24, 48, 72, and 96 h.
Harvest the nematodes in a sterile 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube and wash with M9 buffer >3 times by centrifugation (1000 × g for 1 min) to remove the remaining OP50. Resuspend the AM141 nematodes in M9 buffer, and keep them ready for image acquisition.
Acquisition of fluorescent images and data analysis
	NOTE: Data are automatically analyzed with this high-content imaging system. If an automated imaging device is not available, a conventional method to prepare an agarose pad for image acquisition can be used to achieve similar performance by using a common fluorescent microscope7,15,17 (see steps 3.2 and 3.3).
	
Transfer 10-15 nematodes into each well in a 384-well plate (final volume 80 µL per well). Set 10 replicate wells for each treatment.
Add 10 µL of 200 mM sodium azide to each well to paralyze the nematodes and allow them to settle down to the bottom (5-10 min).
Place the plate in a high-content imaging system to acquire fluorescent images (see the Table of Materials for device and software information).
Open the image acquisition software and set up the following parameters.
		
Open the Plate Acquisition Setup window and create a new experiment set and name.
Select Magnification as 2x, Camera binning as 1, and Plate type as 384-well plate.
Set the wells and sites (single site) to be visited.
Select the fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) filter and enable image-based focusing options.
Set the Exposure as 300 ms.

NOTE: The above settings can be tested and adjusted to optimize the imaging parameters.
Save Image acquisition settings and click on the Acquire Plate button to run.
Analyze the image data by using the image analysis software.
		
Open the Review Plate Data window and select the Test plate for image analysis.
Double-click on a test well to display its image.
Select the Count Nuclei as the analysis method and click on the Configure Settings button to bring out a window for the following settings.
Define the source image from the FITC channel and select the Standard Algorithm.
Set the image analysis parameters as follows: approximate minimum width = 10 µm (= 2 pixels); approximate maximum width = 50 µm (= 12 pixels); intensity above local background = 1,000-2,000 graylevels.
Test the current settings to optimize the method of analysis.
Save the settings and run the analysis on all the wells.
			NOTE: It takes ~20 min to finish analysis for one 384-well plate.
Export the Total Nuclei as the total number of Q40::YFP aggregates in each well.
Count the number of nematodes in each well.
Calculate the average number of Q40::YFP aggregates per nematode in each group, and apply a nonlinear curve fit to the data from each time point.

3. PolyQ-mediated neurotoxicity assays
Treatment of C. elegans with test samples
	
To prepare nematodes for the polyQ neurotoxicity assay, transfer 300-500 synchronized L1 larvae of HA759 to each well of a 48-well plate with 500 µL of S medium containing OP50 (OD570 of 0.7-0.8) and 5 mg/mL of astragalan, typically three replicate wells for each treatment.

Seal the plate with parafilm and incubate at 15 °C and 120 rpm for 3 days23.
Collect the nematodes by centrifugation and wash 3-5 times with M9 buffer. Resuspend the nematodes in M9 buffer for use in neuronal survival and avoidance assays.
Preparation of agarose pad
	
Add 2 g of agarose to 100 mL of M9 buffer (2%, w/v) and heat the agarose solution in a microwave to near-boiling.
Dispense 0.5 mL of melted agarose onto the center of a 1 mm thick microscopy glass slide placed between two pieces of 2 mm thick glass plates. Cover with another slide vertically. Once the agarose cools down and is solidified, gently remove the top slide.
ASH neuronal survival assay
	
Add a drop of 20 mM sodium azide onto the agarose pad. Transfer 15-20 HA759 nematodes into the drop to immobilize them.
Place a coverslip gently over the nematodes. Keep the slide under a fluorescence microscope fitted with a digital camera. Select a 40x objective lens and FITC filter to detect GFP-positive ASH neurons in the head region of the nematodes.
Select more than 50 nematodes in each group randomly to count the number of nematodes with GFP-labeled bilateral ASH neurons in their head region7. Calculate the survival rate of ASH neurons using eq (2) below.
		Neuronal survival (%) = imgsrc://cloudfront.jove.com/files/ftp_upload/63081/63081eq02.jpg (2)
		​Where Nsurvival and Ntotal are the number of nematodes with GFP-positive ASH neurons and the total number of tested nematodes in each group, respectively.
Osmotic avoidance assay

Divide a food-free NGM plate (9 cm) into normal (N) and trap (T) zones by an 8 M glycerol (~30 µL) line in the middle. Spread a 200 mM sodium azide (~20 µL) line at ~1 cm away from the glycerol line to paralyze the nematodes crossing through the glycerol barrier into Zone T.
Transfer ~200 nematodes each onto Zone N of three replicate plates for each group. Add a drop of 1% butanedione (~2 µL) onto Zone T (1 cm from the plate edge) to attract the nematodes. Cover the lid of the Petri dish immediately, and incubate at 23 °C for 90 min.
Score the number of nematodes on the N and T zones under a microscope. Calculate the avoidance index using eq (3)20.
		Avoidance index = imgsrc://cloudfront.jove.com/files/ftp_upload/63081/63081eq03.jpg (3)
		Where N and T are the number of nematodes in N and T zones, respectively. Data are presented as means ± standard deviation (SD) of three replicates, representative of >3 independent experiments.
Perform an unpaired, two-tailed t-test to compare the data from the astragalan and control groups.
4. Creating a radar chart
Open the graphing software and import data from different assays into a new sheet. Input the A(X) column as the titles of the radial axes, A(Y) column as the data from the control group, and B(Y) column as the data from the treatment group.
Select the required data and click on Plot | Specialized: Radar button in the toolbar menu to generate a radar chart.
Double-click on the radial axis and adjust the Scale, Tick, and Tick labels of each axis as needed.
Click on File in the menu and select Export Graphs to save the image as *.tiff.
NOTE: The software websites in the Table of Materials provide detailed help documents and video tutorials on creating radar charts.
